node.title: Experts explain why people are stockpiling toilet paper
node.description: New Zealand's move to red has seen Kiwis start panic buying.
node.content: ["As coronavirus continues to spread\u00a0around the world, anxiety is rising in Australia. Shoppers fearful of quarantine measures have been stocking up on supplies to last out a week or two of isolation.", "Recent days have seen reports of shortages of\u00a0hand sanitiser\u00a0and warnings that\u00a0batteries and other electronic items\u00a0could be next. However, the surge in demand for one particular commodity has seen supermarket shelves stripped bare: toilet paper.", "It\u2019s not just Australians. Shops in\u00a0Japan, the\u00a0US\u00a0and\u00a0New Zealand\u00a0have also run low on the precious sanitary rolls. In Hong Kong, ambitious thieves\u00a0held up a supermarket\u00a0to steal a delivery.", "But why toilet paper? The question has\u00a0been in the air\u00a0for at least the past month, but it\u2019s now become hard to avoid. We asked four experts for their thoughts.", "\"Toilet paper symbolises control. We use it to \u201ctidy up\u201d and \u201cclean up\u201d. It deals with a bodily function that is somewhat taboo,\" he says.", "\"When people hear about the coronavirus, they are afraid of losing control. And toilet paper feels like a way to maintain control over hygiene and cleanliness.", "\"People don\u2019t seem interested in substitutes. Supermarket shelves are still full of other paper towels and tissues.", "\"The media has a lot to answer for in regards to messages around this virus and messages to the public. While honesty about threats is critical, building hysteria and promoting inappropriate behaviours is far from ideal.\"", "\"It\u2019s an interesting question. My suspicion is that it is to do with how people react to stress: they want an element of comfort and security. For many Westerners there is a \u201cyuck factor\u201d associated with non-toilet paper cleaning,\" Cook says.", "\"I expect there is also a pragmatic element. Toilet paper is a product that takes a lot of space, and is therefore not something people have a lot of under normal circumstances.", "\"A lot of people likely also use toilet paper as a tissue, and therefore imagine themselves needing a lot if they have the flu or a flu-like illness.", "\"Stocking up on toilet paper is also a relatively cheap action, and people like to think that they are \u201cdoing something\u201d when they feel at risk.\"", "\"I think it is the perfect product. It is completely non-perishable and one of the few products that you can stock up on that you are guaranteed to use eventually,\" Savage says.", "\"I don\u2019t know for certain but I suspect that most people only buy toilet paper when they just about run out, which could be a problem if you need to stay isolated for two weeks.", "\"So I think this is just a preparation process, because we have seen that toilet paper has become a shortage item elsewhere.\"", "\"There are a few factors at play here. People aren\u2019t only stockpiling toilet paper. All sorts of items are sold out, like face masks and hand sanitiser. Things like canned goods and other non-perishable foods are also selling well,\" Russell says.\u00a0", "\"People are scared, and they\u2019re bunkering down. They\u2019re buying what they need and one of the items is toilet paper.", "\"I think we\u2019re noticing the toilet paper more than the other things because toilet paper packs are big items that take up a lot of shelf space. Seeing a small product sold out at the supermarket (such as hand sanitiser) is not that unusual, and it\u2019s only a small hole in the shelf that is often temporarily filled with nearby products.", "\"But if the toilet paper is gone, that\u2019s a massive amount of shelf space that can\u2019t readily be replaced with other things nearby.", "\"A second reason we might be noticing it more is because there aren\u2019t easy substitutions. If the supermarket is out of a particular ingredient for dinner, you can just get something else, or an entirely different dinner.", "\"But if there\u2019s not a roll of toilet paper, then that\u2019s pretty frustrating for everyone. Sure, tissues or paper towels, but it\u2019s not quite the same, is it?\"", "The Conversation"]
